channel.title: zettel on lukhen
channel.description: Recent content in zettel on lukhen

item.title: create a file with a similar name in emacs with avy
item.description: creating a file with a name that is similar to the one that already exists ex. “file1” exists, and you want to create “file”. C-M-j - go with current input instead of the current candidate

item.title: exporting to hugo
git, remove previously added file from tracking
Dependency injection with reader monad.
item.description: Dependency injection with reader monad in typescript with fp-ts: Change the signature of a function f: a->b to f: a->Reader<x, b> Change the signatures of all functions that call f (g: c -> d) to c -> Reader<x, d> Change all failing tests by introducing some fake x. Example We have a type: interface Book { title: string author: string } a database: const books: Book[] = [ { title: "Iliad", author: "Homer" }, { title: "For whom the bell tolls", author: "Ernest Hemingway" }, { title: "Treasure Island", author: "Robert Louis Stevenson" } ] 2 functions, where one is a dependency of the other:

item.title: Simple lens and traversal (optics in typescript with fp-ts)
do notation, aps
item.description: I like to use “do” notation with Either/TaskEither monads which I often use. declare const fetchX: () => E.Either<Error, number> declare const fetchY: () => E.Either<Error, string> Let’s imagine we need both x and y. pipe( fetchX, fetchY ) is wrong. Before I learned to use “do” I used to handle this problem like so: pipe( [fetchX(), fetchY()] as [E.Either<Error, number>, E.Either<Error, string>], (t) => sequenceT(E.either)(...t), // convert a tuple of eithers to either of tuple E.

item.title: exit status of a shell command
item.description: Exit status of a command: 0 - ok 1 - minor problems 2 - serious trouble a command returns exit status of its subcommand or by using “exit x”

item.title: starting nodejs project with typescript and jest
Run shell on a docker container
item.description: docker exec -ti container-name /bin/sh or /bin/bash // docker run –interactive –tty –entrypoint /bin/sh container-namei

item.title: Clean disk space (docker)
item.description: disk space ran out: sudo du -shc /var/* - show disk usage of each folder in /var docker image prune docker image prune -a docker container prune docker volume prune docker network prune

item.title: org mode and roam useful keybindings and functions
item.description: C-c C-t - change todo S-M-RET (org-insert-todo-heading) Insert a new TODO entry below the current one. M-Ret Insert new entry reload, sync database of org-roam org-roam-db-sync add CREATED property add-created-property open link at point C-c C-o find all notes published org-agenda -> tags -> published find all notes concerning a project C-c n l on project node

item.title: About
item.description: Me My name is ≈Åukasz. I’m a longterm web programmer. After graduation I did a strange thing and I took a non-porgramming job (as a manager in a family company). That is why I can’t show my programming commercial experience. But code have always flown in my veins, and within years I did a lot of different things. I’d gladly join a team as a junior. My skills: tdd functional programming object oriented programming Programming languages: typescript python javascript racket c++ (long ago) c# (long ago) haskell (very little) Technologies/frameworks I have worked with: nodejs deno react docker linux nginx python web frameworks: pyramid flask emacs (my IDE) Site This site is to present myself, my skills, projects that I have worked on, and to share things, if anyone sees them useful.

item.title: list roam files that were not published (grep)
new haskell project in lukhemacs
item.description: Haskell config: install ghcup with with hls (here): curl –proto ‘=https’ –tlsv1.2 -sSf https://get-ghcup.haskell.org | sh mkdir project cabal init cabal docs and simple tut cabal install implicit-hie gen-hie > hie.yaml (to make lsp-haskell work)

item.title: pushing and pulling to github
item.description: wrong each repo has to have its own ssh key repo ssh keys are used in advanced configurations it’s enough to set profile ssh key, ssh-add the key sometimes it’s neccessary to flush key-ring ssh-add -D pushing ssh-add ~/Desktop/droplet1_rsa magit push pulling on remote: eval `ssh-agent -s` ssh-add ~/.ssh/github git pull
